title: User Tutorial: Registering for an Account
description: Watch this tutorial to see how to register for a Public, Teacher or Student Account.

title: User Tutorial: An overview of the AT simulator and features
description: Watch this tutorial to see the different features of the Alberta Tomorrow Simulator.

title: User Tutorial: Your Mission
description: An overview of the mission you will accomplish using Alberta Tomorrow

title: User Tutorial: Running a Historical Simulation in Alberta Tomorrow
description: Watch this video to find out how your study area has changed since 1910!

title: User Tutorial: How to Create a Business as Usual (BAU) Scenario
description: A BAU scenario gives you a glimpse of a possible future, one that carries current trends in landuse into the future.

title: User Tutorial: How to Create your own Land Use Scenarios
description: This video will show you how to select your watershed study area, set goals, make changes on the map, and run your scenario.

title: User Tutorial: How to Create an Observation in the Simulator
description: This tutorial walks you through how to create your own observation in the simulator that you and all registered users can see.

title: User Tutorial: Investigating Climate Change Scenarios in Alberta Tomorrow
description: See how you can view changes that may occur due to climate change with Mild, Medium or Hot Climate Change Scenarios.

title: User Tutorial: Creating and Sharing a Report in Alberta Tomorrow
description: This short tutorial video will show you how to create and share a report in the simulator.

title: Climate Change
description: How will Alberta be affected by Climate Change? What's the difference between Climate Change and Global Warming?

title: Beneficial Management Practices
description: What are Beneficial Management Practices and how do they affect the future of Alberta? Find out what large companies, farmers, and you can do to minimize the effect on the environment.

title: Ecological Goods and Services
description: An introduction to ecological goods and services.

title: Water Quality, Climate Change and Alberta's Glaciers Webinar
description: This webinar was held on May 27, 2020 and features 4 prominent scientists talking about climate change and how it will affect glaciers, glacier melt, water policy and our water quality.

title: Natural Landscapes
description: Prior to Alberta's European Settlement, 100% of the landscape was considered natural. Learn more about Alberta's natural landscapes and how best practices can reduce the footprint of development.

title: Caribou Habitat
description: Explore how caribou habitat is impacted by human development and how best practices can reduce disturbances in their environment.

title: Grizzly Habitat
description: Learn how forest development and human activity affect the suitability of grizzly bear habitat across Alberta.

title: Fish Habitat
description: Discover how land use affects fish community health, from native trout populations to the impacts of angling and habitat disturbance.

title: Water Quality
description: Explore how phosphorus runoff from agriculture and settlement impacts aquatic ecosystems and how best practices can improve water quality.

title: Greenhouse Gasses
description: Understand how greenhouse gas emissions are linked to population and resource production, and how best practices can cut emissions.

title: Human Population
description: Maximum population growth is assumed to be a doubling of the population. Learn more about Alberta's projected population and land use impacts.

title: Gross Domestic Product
description: GDP is based on land use for oil and gas, forestry, and agriculture. Learn how economic development influences Alberta's GDP.

title: Hydrocarbon Production
description: Hydrocarbon production includes natural gas, oil, bitumen, and coal. Learn how energy production affects land use and the economy.

title: Timber Production
description: A value of 100% means all forested land is used for timber. Explore how forestry contributes to the economy and affects land use.

title: Agricultural Production
description: Learn how using the landscape for agriculture contributes to food production and economic development in Alberta.

title: Water Consumption
description: Learn how agricultural, settlement, and industrial use affect water consumption and how best practices can reduce demand.

title: TLU Access
description: Traditional Land Use Access (TLU Access) measures land accessibility for Indigenous peoples engaging in traditional practices. It reflects accessible natural areas not within protected zones.

title: Moose Habitat
description: Moose Habitat is reduced by industrial development and proximity to human activity. This video explores how habitat value is calculated in Alberta Tomorrow.

title: Hunting Opportunity
description: This video explains the Hunting Opportunity indicator, combining TLU Access and Moose Habitat to reflect Indigenous hunting access.

title: Water Quality
description: Phosphorus runoff and land conversion reduce water quality. Learn how Indigenous communities are impacted and how this indicator is measured.

title: Fish Habitat
description: Healthy fish habitat means diverse native species and fewer disturbances. This video highlights habitat importance to Indigenous communities.

title: Fishing Opportunity
description: Fishing Opportunity combines TLU Access and Fish Habitat to indicate access to successful fishing activities for Indigenous peoples.

title: Watershed 360° Tour
description: Visit each sub-basin in the Bow River basin and get a feel for how people use the water and the landscape. Look at the different types of buildings, pathways, and activities that can take place within the watershed as you travel from the headwaters, down to the end in the prairies.

title: Hydrology and Climate Change
description: Tricia Stadnyk talks about how a watershed can affect the climate it is in, and in turn, how the climate then affects the landscape. Go from the headwaters through to the prairies as she talks about precipitation and more.

title: Watershed Management and Data
description: Dr. Lee Jackson talks about the Sustainable Watershed Integrated Management Platform and the necessity of shared water data for the health of the Bow River Basin. Explore from the headwaters into the prairies and learn about citizen science projects, and different data parameters.

title: Watersheds and Hydrology
description: Go from the mountains through the river basin while learning what a watershed is, and how hydrology is apparent in the landscape. Tricia Stadnyk will explain how hydrology can affect everything around it as you explore.

title: Hydrology and Land Development
description: Explore the watershed while Tricia Stadnyk explains how landscapes and water are affected by development and use changes. How does hydrology within the watershed change when the landscape changes because of humans?

title: Elbow River Watershed Partnership (ERWP) Aquifers
description: Explore the Elbow River watershed and learn about its groundwater, and state of the aquifer with Joe and Flora. Learn the definitions for what an aquifer is, how groundwater is used in the sub-basin, and how it is affected by people.

title: Wetlands and Stormwater
description: Take a walk around the constructed wetlands in North Glenmore park with Liliana Bozic as she explains the uses of wetlands for storage and stormwater. Learn how water quality is affected by wetlands, and how land development changes, and seasons affect them.

title: Water Quality
description: Join Patrick Van den Eynden as he talks about the City of Calgary’s Glenmore Water Treatment Plant’s process from getting the water from the reservoir, all the way to disinfection and sending the water out to service sites across the city.

title: Water Services
description: Explore some of the Glenmore dam and reservoir as Patrick Van den Eynden talks about its history, infrastructure, services, and the City’s water drinking system.

lessonPlans.title: Glenmore Dam and Resevoir: Water Services

title: Native Prairies and Plants
description: As Megan Evans and Erin Anderson talk about the importance of prairies and their native plants, explore several grassland landscapes within the Bow River Basin.

title: Invasive Species and Control
description: Learn about invasive species in native grasslands, control systems, and the importance of native species from Erin Anderson and Megan Evans as you explore various prairie landscapes.

title: Isotopes and Climate Change
description: Learn about how isotopes can be used to monitor climate change and hydrologic functions within a watershed.

title: Are people affecting the glaciers?
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about how people are affecting the glaciers.

title: Colour of the ice
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about why glacier ice is sometimes blue.

title: Glaciers move
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about how glaciers move.

title: How crevasses form
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about how crevasses form in glaciers.

title: How do forest fires affect glaciers
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about how summer forest fires affect the glaciers.

title: Is it important glaciers are in the national park?
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux discuss why it's important to have glaciers protected in National Parks.

title: Seasonal change on the glacier and cryconite
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about seasonal changes on the glacier.

title: Striations on the Rocks
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about how glaciers can cause striations on rocks as they move.

title: What is a moraine
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux discuss the different types of glacial moraine.

title: Where do glaciers form?
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux discuss where glaciers form in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Where does water from the Snowdome go?
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux as he discusses where water from Snowdome ends up.

title: Where was the Athabasca glacier in 2006?
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about how fare the glacier has receded since 2006 and how he knows!

title: Where was the glacier in 1982 and what is a lateral moraine?
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux as he discusses where the Athabasca glacier was in 1982.

title: Where will the glacier be in 30 years?
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux as he discussed where the Athabasca Glacier may be in 30 years.

title: Come with us to the Athabasca Glacier
description: Walk with us the the Athabasca Glacier on the Columbia Icefield.

title: How Glaciers Move
description: Peter Lemieux discusses how Glaciers move.

title: How much glacial ice are we losing?
description: Watch as Peter Lemieux discusses how much ice the Athabasca Glacier is losing in one season an how he knows this.

title: Why are some lakes blue?
description: What this video as Peter Lemieux discusses why some glacier lakes are blue.

title: Why should we protect glaciers?
description: Watch as Peter Lemieux discusses why it is so important to protect our glaciers.

title: This is the Athabasca glacier.
description: Walk with us to the Athabasca Glacier.

title: Endocrine Disruptors
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello talks about melting glaciers and what this has to do with Endocrine Disruptors.

title: Forest Fires and Glaciers
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses the effects of forest fires on Alberta Glaciers.

title: Glacial Albedo
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses what Albedo is and how it relates to Alberta glaciers.

title: Growth and Attrition
description: Listen to Dr. Ali Criscitiello discuss growth and attrition of Alberta Glaciers

title: How human activity affects Alberta glaciers.
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello talks about how human activity affects Alberta Glaciers.

title: How do chemicals that were trapped in Alberta glaciers get into our water?
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses how chemicals, once trapped in frozen ice, will get into our water supply, even some that were banned years ago!

title: Ion chromatrograph
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello talks about the Ion Chromatograph and what it tells us about the glaciers.

title: Measuring Isotopes
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses how her equipment measures oxygen isotopes in Alberta glaciers and what this tells us .

title: Persistent Chemicals in Alberta Glaciers
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses what persistent  chemicals are and the danger of them being released after being trapped in Alberta glacier ice.

title: What is the Picarro machine and what does it do?
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello of the Canadian Ice Core Lab discusses some of the technology she uses to study Alberta glaciers.

title: Sea level rise
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses how glaciers contribute to sea level rise.

title: Watershed Great Divide - Where does water from the Columbia Icefield go?
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello talks about meltwater from the Columbia Icefield and where it eventually ends up.

title: What can we do to protect Alberta glaciers?
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello talks about what we can do to protect Alberta glaciers.

title: Where do we find glaciers?
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses where we find glaciers.

title: Why are Alberta glaciers important?
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discuss the importance of Alberta Glaciers.

title: Why protect Alberta glaciers?
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello discusses why it is important to protect Alberta Glaciers.

title: Cutting Glacier Ice Cores
description: Cutting Ice Cores at the Canadian Ice Core Lab

title: How Cold is the freezer in the Canadian Ice Core Lab?
description: Dr. Alison Criscitiello demonstrated how she cuts ice cores for analysis at the Canadian Ice Core Lab at the University of Alberta.

title: Getting suited up to enter the Canadian Ice Core Lab
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello gets prepared to go into the Canadian Ice Core Lab.

title: Into the cold
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello takes us into the freezer of the Canadian Ice Core Lab.

title: Into the Lab
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello takes us into the lab used to study Alberta glaciers.

title: How big is the Athabasca Glacier
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about the size of the Athabasca Glacier.

title: Every year its further to get to work
description: Listen to Peter Lemieux talk about the receding of the Athabasca Glacier.

title: Dr. Criscitiello and her research
description: Dr. Ali Criscitiello talks about how she got interested in studying glaciers and what she does at the Canadian Ice Core Lab.

title: Consulting With The Stoney
description: The Stoney people want to be included in discussions about the future of Stoney lands. Listen to Elders talk about what they use the land for.

title: Cement Factory
description: The Cement factory has been around for a long time.  Listen to Elder Lawrence talk about how Exshaw got it's name and  the impact of the plant on the Stoney people.

title: The Railway
description: Elder Lawrence talks about the railway as it goes through Stoney Territory.

title: Using Land For Protection
description: Learn how the Stoney people used the land for protection.

title: Glaciers
description: Elder Margaret talks about her experience on the Columbia Ice field and what she thinks should be done.

title: Creator Story
description: According to the Stoney, Jasper down to the US is their land.  This is where creator put them.

title: Reclimatizing in the Sibbald
description: Travis discusses how the Sibbald area was used by the Stoney people to reacclimatize back to Mountain elevations after travelling south.

title: Before Treaty
description: Elder Margaret is asked to describe the Stoney people before Treaty was signed.

title: Life Of A Stoney Boy
description: Listen to Elder Terry tell a story from his youth.

title: Bringing Back the Bison
description: Travis talks about reintroducing Bison back on the landscape.

title: Yamnuska Meaning
description: Lean how this iconic mountain in the Alberta Rocky Mountains got it's name.

title: Cougar Story
description: Elder Lawrence talks about how Cougar Mountain got its name.

title: Food and Camp
description: How did the Stoney people survive off the land, especially in the winter?  Watch to find out.

title: Concept of Time
description: Travis talks about differences in the concept of time. The oral tradition says "Back in time".  Stoney used the surroundings and animals to tell time, seasons and the weather. "The Sky was the clock, the moon, the stars."

title: What Will Land Look Like In The Future
description: What is your hope for the future?

title: Great Depression
description: Elder Lawrence talks about the Stoney experience during the Great Depression.

title: Water - Now and The Future
description: Listen to Elder Margaret talk about the importance of Water to the Stoney People and to everyone.

title: Stoney Voice At The Table
description: Land Use planning in Alberta needs to include a Stoney Voice.

title: Fishing On The Bow
description: The Stoney used to use the fish from the Bow River, but they don't eat the fish anymore. They enjoy the river but they don't eat the fish.

title: Tornado
description: Travis talks about how he was taught to survive a Tornado on Stoney territory.

title: Using The Land
description: Listen to Elders talk about how the Stoney people used the land.

title: Moose Story
description: Moose in Stoney Territory. Are there as many now as there were in the past?

title: Land Use and Wildlife
description: Travis talks about how wildlife populations have changed on Stoney territory and what needs to be done to protect from further loss.  "We are coming into the home of the four legged and winged ones and need to be mindful of what we're doing".

title: Protected Areas
description: The Sibbald area is an area used for camping and recreation but does that compatible with the Stoney Traditional Land Uses?

title: Reconcili-ACTION
description: Elder Terry talks about the need for ReconciliACTION after Reconciliation.

title: First Contact With Settlers
description: Travis recalls stories of Stoney encountering Settlers for the first time.

title: Access To Land - Sibbald Flats
description: Listen to Elders talk about the  importance of the Sibbald Flats for hunting, collecting berries and traditional uses and the incompatibility with some other land uses.

title: Introductions
description: Meet the Elders from the Stoney Nakoda Nation who made this video series possible.

title: A Blackfoot Perspective on Water
description: A video sharing the Blackfoot perspective on water and its significance in Indigenous culture and the environment.

title: Investigating a Fish Kill
description: Michael Sullivan, provincial fish science specialist with Alberta Fish and Wildlife talks at Lake Isle where thousands of sucker fish are poking their heads out of the water literally gasping for air because of oxygen deficiency in the water in this video from March 2014.

title: Native Trout in Alberta
description: Watch this recording of a LiveStream presented by CPAWS SAB, Trout Unlimited and Cows and Fish to learn about Native Trout in Alberta.

title: Athabasca Sand Dunes Ecological Reserve
description: Open, moving sand dunes surrounded by lakes.

title: Writing on Stone Provincial Park
description: Learn about the landforms and the significance of the area to the Blackfoot people.

title: Hanging Culvert
description: Listen to this fisheries biologist explain what a hanging culvert is in the upper reaches of the Red Deer River Watershed.

title: Forest Attack - Mountain Pine Beetle
description: Follow biologists as they look for trees attacked by Mountain Pine Beetles.

title: Grassland Restoration
description: This ranch south of Manyberries is an Alberta Conservation Association site.

title: Beneath the Surface: Water Monitoring in the Ghost Watershed
description: Peek into a bucket of bugs and see why these aquatic invertebrates are indicators of water quality.

title: Finding Water: Healthy Land, Healthy Stream
description: A documentary video on the sources of Canada’s prairie rivers and their vulnerability to land use.

title: Oxygen Isotopes and the Paleoclimate Record
description: A brief explanation of oxygen isotopes, and how the oxygen isotope signal can be used to study past climates.

title: Hydrolysis and the Faint Young Sun Paradox
description: The chemical weathering of continental rocks (hydrolysis) removes CO2 from the atmosphere over geologic time. Could this explain why the Earth was not frozen in its early history when the sun was very faint?

title: Introducing Alberta Tomorrow’s 360 Virtual Field Trips
description: The time has finally come! Check out the 360 Virtual Field Trips to Alberta's Ecoregions!  1 for each ecoregion exploring the plants, animals, geology, landforms, climate, land uses and species at risk! Register for your Alberta Tomorrow account at www.albertatomorrow.ca to gain access TODAY!
